4 Sec. 56.5. 1. The Education Service Center is hereby
5 created as an educational service agency for the purpose of acting
6 as an educational service agency under 34 C.F.R. § 300.12 to
7 develop, manage and provide services and programs to local
8 educational agencies and, as necessary, to other local
9 governments.
10 2. The governing body of the Education Service Center is the
11 Board of the Education Service Center, which must consist of the
12 following members:
13 (a) Two members appointed by the Governor;
14 (b) One member, who must not be a Legislator, appointed by
15 the Majority Leader of the Senate;
16 (c) One member, who must not be a Legislator, appointed by
17 the Minority Leader of the Senate;
18 (d) One member, who must not be a Legislator, appointed by
19 the Speaker of the Assembly;
20 (e) One member, who must not be a Legislator, appointed by
21 the Minority Leader of the Assembly; and
22 (f) One member appointed by the State Board.
23 3. The Superintendent of Public Instruction shall call the
24 first meeting of the Board of the Education Service Center. At its
25 first meeting and annually thereafter, the members of the Board
26 shall elect a Chair and Vice Chair from among the members of the
27 Board. After its first meeting, the Board shall meet as needed at
28 the call of the Chair.
29 4. Each member of the Board of the Education Service
30 Center:
31 (a) Serves without compensation; and
32 (b) While engaged in the business of the Education Service
33 Center, is entitled to receive the travel expenses provided for state
34 officers and employees generally.
35 5. Each member of the Board of the Education Service
36 Center serves a term of 2 years and may be reappointed for
37 additional terms of 2 years in the same manner as the original
38 appointment. Any vacancy occurring in the membership of the
39 Board must be filled in the same manner as the original
40 appointment not later than 30 days after the vacancy occurs.
41 6. Within the limits of available money:
42 (a) The Board of the Education Service Center may appoint an
43 Executive Director. The Executive Director shall not pursue any
44 other business or occupation or hold any other office of profit
45 without the approval of the Board.

34 Sec. 58.7. Chapter 394 of NRS is hereby amended by adding
35 thereto a new section to read as follows:
36 1. A school employee is immune from both criminal and civil
37 liability for actions taken in good faith to intervene in physical
38 altercations, fights or other incidents that pose an imminent risk to
39 the safety of pupils, other school employees and persons in
40 proximity to the altercation, fight or incident, provided that:
41 (a) The school employee is acting within the course and scope
42 of his or her employment and within the course and scope of his
43 or her role in maintaining order, discipline or the safety of pupils;
44 (b) The actions of the school employee are consistent with
45 federal, state and local laws and the policies of the school district
-
*SB460_R2*
– 169 –
1 employing the school employee or the school at which the school
2 employee is employed relating to the maintenance of safety and
3 discipline; and
4 (c) Any harm caused by the intervention was not the result of:
5 (1) Willful or intentional misconduct;
6 (2) Gross negligence;
7 (3) Reckless misconduct; or
8 (4) A conscious, flagrant indifference to the rights or safety
9 of the person harmed.
10 2. If any school employee intervenes in a fight or altercation
11 involving a pupil, the school employee shall report the incident to
12 school administration as soon as practicable and in accordance
13 with the policies and protocols established by the school employing
14 the school employee.
15 3. Each school shall maintain a record of reports received
16 pursuant to subsection 2 and use these records only to assess the
17 need for additional training, support or policy adjustments to
18 improve school safety practices.
19 4. As used in this section:
20 (a) “Intervene” or “intervention” means taking any physical
21 or verbal action to prevent, separate or otherwise manage pupils in
22 a manner designed to avoid imminent harm to pupils, school
23 employees or others in proximity to the area where such actions
24 are taken.
25 (b) “School employee” means a licensed or unlicensed person
26 who is employed by a private school.

11 any criminal history of a person who is licensed by the

22 Next Generation Identification Systems, including, without
23 limitation, latent fingerprint searches.

37 Department of Education.

*SB460_R2*
– 171 –

4 electronic fingerprint cards or facsimiles of fingerprints that the

6 Rap Back Program.

10 ongoing status notifications of any criminal history reported for

35 fiscal year in an amount equal to 4 percent or less of the actual

37 and the local government employer has provided a written

24 such a school.

12 Sec. 69. 1. The Nevada Registered Teacher Apprenticeship
13 Support Account is hereby created in the State General Fund. The
14 Account must be administered by the State Apprenticeship
15 Director.
16 2. The interest and income earned on:
17 (a) The money in the Account, after deducting any applicable
18 charges; and
19 (b) Unexpended appropriations made to the Account from the
20 State General Fund,
21  must be credited to the Account.
22 3. Any money remaining in the Account at the end of a fiscal
23 year, including, without limitation, any unexpended
24 appropriations made to the Account from the State General Fund,
25 reverts to the State General Fund.
26 4. The State Apprenticeship Director may accept gifts and
27 grants of money from any source for deposit in the Account.
28 5. The money in the Account may only be used to provide
29 grants of money pursuant to section 70 of this act.
30 Sec. 70. 1. The Nevada Registered Teacher Apprenticeship
31 Support Program is hereby created in the Office of Labor
32 Commissioner. The purpose of the program is to provide grants of
33 money to sponsors of apprenticeship programs in teaching that
34 have been approved by the Council to provide:
35 (a) Wrap-around support and staffing services to recruit,
36 prepare and retain apprentices participating in an apprenticeship
37 program in teaching who desire to become licensed teachers in
38 public schools in this State; and
39 (b) Instruction, including, without limitation, professional
40 development, coaching, mentoring and induction required during
41 an apprenticeship in teaching.
42 2. The State Apprenticeship Director shall:
43 (a) Administer the Program.
44 (b) Establish requirements for eligibility to participate in the
45 Program, including, without limitation, requiring an applicant to:
-
*SB460_R2*
– 182 –
1 (1) Establish that the apprenticeship program sponsored by
2 the applicant has been approved by the Council pursuant to
3 NRS 610.095;
4 (2) Use evidence-based metrics to evaluate the success of
5 the apprenticeship program; and
6 (3) Demonstrate the capability of the applicant to
7 successfully recruit participants for the program, prepare the
8 participants to become teachers and retain the participants in a
9 public school in this State; and
10 (c) Evaluate applications submitted pursuant to this section.
11 3. In evaluating an application for a grant of money awarded
12 pursuant to this section, the State Apprenticeship Director shall
13 give priority to an applicant who:
14 (a) Complies with the requirements of subsection 2;
15 (b) Demonstrates previous success in carrying out an
16 apprenticeship program;
17 (c) Provides a plan for new or innovative wrap-around
18 supports that are determined to be of high quality by the State
19 Apprenticeship Director; and
20 (d) Provides a plan to efficiently use the grant of money
21 awarded pursuant to this section to maximize the number of
22 participants in an apprenticeship program who will benefit from
23 its use.
24 4. An applicant who receives a grant of money pursuant to
25 this section shall:
26 (a) Develop, in collaboration with the State Apprenticeship
27 Director, standards and goals for the program to meet, including,
28 without limitation, a desired number of pupils to participate in and
29 complete the apprenticeship program;
30 (b) Provide wrap-around services to participants in the
31 apprenticeship program; and
32 (c) Submit a report to the State Apprenticeship Director at the
33 end of each semester describing the progress of the apprenticeship
34 program in achieving the goals developed pursuant to
35 paragraph (a).
36 5. The State Apprenticeship Director shall ensure that:
37 (a) Grants of money are promptly distributed to applicants
38 selected to receive such a grant; and
39 (b) Grants of money are awarded proportional to the number
40 of participants in the apprenticeship program, provided that:
41 (1) Not more than $4,000 is awarded for each participant;
42 and
43 (2) A participant is counted for the purposes of calculating
44 the amount of a grant for not more than 2 years.
-
*SB460_R2*
– 183 –
1 6. Not more than 5 percent of a grant of money awarded
2 pursuant to this section may be expended by the recipient to cover
3 costs related to facilities and administration of the apprenticeship
4 program for which the recipient is the sponsor.
5 7. The State Apprenticeship Director shall enter into
6 agreements with applicants selected to receive a grant pursuant to
7 this section to ensure the collection and analysis of data relating to
8 the evaluation and identification of metrics concerning
9 apprenticeship programs supported by the grant, including,
10 without limitation:
11 (a) Enrollment in the apprenticeship program;
12 (b) Demographic information of the participants in the
13 apprenticeship program;
14 (c) Retention and graduation rates for the program;
15 (d) The number of apprentices who were subsequently
16 employed by a public school in this State during the 3 years after
17 graduation; and
18 (e) The results of any surveys conducted of participants
19 concerning the effectiveness of the apprenticeship program and
20 any deficits in resources made available to a participant during his
21 or her participation in the apprenticeship program.
22 8. On or before June 30 of each year, the State
23 Apprenticeship Director shall prepare a report on the status of the
24 Program and the effectiveness of the grants awarded pursuant to
25 this section and submit the report to the:
26 (a) Governor; and
27 (b) Director of the Legislative Counsel Bureau for transmittal
28 to the Joint Interim Standing Committee on Education.

3 Counsel Bureau for transmittal to the 84th Session of the Nevada
4 Legislature.
5 Sec. 81.5. 1. One or more institutions within the Nevada
6 System of Higher Education may establish and operate a pilot
7 program to offer an alternative pathway for assessing the
8 competency of applicants for a license to teach pupils in this State
9 through the use of alternative assessment methods.
10 2. A pilot program established pursuant to subsection 1 must:
11 (a) Select not more than 100 participants for the pilot program
12 each academic year;
13 (b) Select not more than 25 teachers licensed pursuant to chapter
14 391 of NRS who have taught in a public school in this State for at
15 least 5 years to serve as mentors for participants in the pilot
16 program;
17 (c) Include a curriculum of professional development for
18 participants in the pilot program that consists of at least 10 sessions
19 and is aligned with the criteria for designating a teacher as effective
20 or highly effective under the statewide performance evaluation
21 system established by the State Board of Education pursuant to
22 NRS 391.465;
23 (d) Require, for the duration of the pilot program, a teacher
24 selected to serve as a mentor pursuant to paragraph (b) to conduct a
25 monthly meeting with each participant who is assigned as his or her
26 mentee;
27 (e) For a participant to receive credit for satisfactorily
28 completing the pilot program, require the participant to, while he or
29 she is participating in the pilot program, receive at least two
30 consecutive evaluations, conducted pursuant to NRS 391.685, in
31 which the overall performance of the teacher was designated as
32 effective or highly effective;
33 (f) For alternative assessment methods, assess the validity and
34 reliability of the methods and ability of the methods to be scaled to
35 accommodate a greater number of participants;
36 (g) Promote assessment practices that are inclusive and
37 equitable and that support a diversity of learning styles and
38 experiences;
39 (h) Align alternative assessment methods with applicable state
40 standards, requirements for accreditation and the needs of school
41 districts in this State; and
42 (i) Collect and analyze data to provide evidence-based
43 recommendations for the potential implementation of alternative
44 assessment methods in this State.
-
*SB460_R2*
– 192 –
1 3. A person is eligible to participate in a pilot program
2 established pursuant to this section if he or she is an applicant for a
3 license to teach issued pursuant to chapter 391 of NRS and holds;
4 (a) A provisional license issued by the Superintendent of Public
5 Instruction pursuant to NRS 391.032;
6 (b) A special license as an emergency substitute teacher issued
7 by the Department of Education; or
8 (c) An endorsement to serve as a substitute teacher in early
9 childhood education through grade 12 issued by the State Board of
10 Education.
11 4. The Department of Education shall:
12 (a) For each participant in the pilot program established
13 pursuant to this section, extend for 24 months after selection
14 participate in the pilot program any deadline for removing a
15 provision on a provisional license issued by the Superintendent of
16 Public Instruction pursuant to NRS 391.032 that requires
17 successfully passing a competency test required to receive an initial
18 license to teach pursuant to NRS 391.021.
19 (b) Upon successful completion of the pilot program by a
20 participant who holds a provisional license issued by the
21 Superintendent of Public Instruction pursuant to NRS 391.032,
22 remove any provision on the provisional license issued to the
23 applicant which requires the applicant to pass a competency test in
24 the principles and methods of teaching.
25 5. Each institution that offers a pilot program pursuant to this
26 section shall:
27 (a) On or before July 1 of each year of operation of the pilot
28 program established pursuant to this section:
29 (1) Compile a report describing the progress of the pilot
30 program, including, without limitation:
31 (I) Demographic information for participants in the pilot
32 program;
33 (II) The success of professional development services
34 provided by the pilot program;
35 (III) Preliminary findings of the pilot program.
36 (2) Submit the report compiled pursuant to subparagraph (1)
37 to:
38 (I) The Director of the Legislative Counsel Bureau for
39 transmittal to the Joint Interim Standing Committee on Education;
40 (II) The State Board of Education; and
41 (III) The Commission on Professional Standards in
42 Education.
43 (b) Not later than 6 months after the pilot program established
44 pursuant to this section ceases operation, submit to the Department
45 of Education:
-
*SB460_R2*
– 193 –
1 (1) A plan for implementing the pilot program in a
2 permanent format that can accommodate all prospective applicants
3 that describes the structure and curriculum of the pilot program; and
4 (2) The metrics of success for the pilot program.
5 6. As used in this section:
6 (a) “Alternative assessment methods” means valid and reliable
7 methods used for determining, for an initial license to teach issued
8 pursuant to NRS 391.019, the applicant’s competency in, knowledge
9 of and ability to provide instruction in accordance with sound
10 principles and methods of teaching appropriate to the applicant’s
11 required level of competence that is equivalent to the “Principles of
12 Learning and Teaching Test” prepared and administered by the
13 Educational Testing Service.
14 (b) “Metrics of success” includes, without limitation:
15 (1) An evaluation of the growth in competency, professional
16 engagement and readiness for participants in the pilot program
17 established pursuant to this section;
18 (2) An analysis of the impact of the pilot program on the
19 retention, effectiveness and morale of teachers; and
20 (3) Benchmarks for satisfactory completion of the pilot
21 program.
22 (c) “Participant” means an applicant for a license to teach who is
23 selected to participate in the pilot program established pursuant to
24 this section.
25 Sec. 82. The provisions of NRS 354.599 do not apply to any
26 additional expenses of a local government that are related to the
27 provisions of this act.
28 Sec. 83. 1. Notwithstanding the provisions of NRS 391.033,
29 as amended by section 43 of this act, and NRS 391.040, as amended
30 by section 45 of this act, an applicant for the renewal of a license
31 issued by the Superintendent of Public Instruction must submit with
32 the first renewal of his or her license after July 1, 2029.
33 (a) A complete set of his or her fingerprints and written
34 permission authorizing the Superintendent to forward the
35 fingerprints to the Central Repository for Nevada Records of
36 Criminal History for its report on the criminal history of the
37 applicant, and for submission to the Federal Bureau of Investigation
38 for its report on the criminal history of the applicant; and
39 (b) Any fees for processing the fingerprints of the applicant for
40 renewal by the Central Repository for Nevada Records of Criminal
41 History and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Any fees required
42 by this paragraph must not cause the fees for the renewal of a
43 license to exceed the amount fixed by the Commission on
44 Professional Standards in Education pursuant to NRS 391.040, as
45 that section existed before July 1, 2026.

8 Nevada Revised Statutes, use the authority set forth in NRS 220.120
9 to substitute appropriately the term:
10 1. “Focus” for the term “low-performing” as previously used in

12 school or school.

14 used in reference to an underperforming school district or sponsor of
15 a charter school or persistently underperforming school.

Raw Text:
(Reprinted with amendments adopted on June 2, 2025)
SECOND REPRINT S.B. 460
SENATE BILL NO. 460–SENATORS CANNIZZARO, DONDERO LOOP,
PAZINA; CRUZ-CRAWFORD, DALY, DOÑATE, FLORES,
LANGE, NEAL, NGUYEN, OHRENSCHALL, SCHEIBLE AND
TAYLOR
APRIL 29, 2025
____________
Referred to Committee on Education
SUMMARY—Revises provisions relating to education.
(BDR 34-16)
FISCAL NOTE: Effect on Local Government: May have Fiscal Impact.
Effect on the State: Contains Appropriation not included
in Executive Budget.
CONTAINS UNFUNDED MANDATE (§§ 1.3, 8.7, 14, 15, 28, 30, 33, 34, 56.2)
(NOT REQUESTED BY AFFECTED LOCAL GOVERNMENT)
~
EXPLANATION – Matter in bolded italics is new; matter between brackets [omitted material] is material to be omitted.
AN ACT relating to education; revising provisions governing plans
to improve academic achievement; providing for the
waiver of certain reporting requirements; revising
provisions governing the annual report of accountability
for a school district; revising the duties of the
Commission on Innovation and Excellence in Education;
providing for the impaneling of a Public Education
Oversight Board; revising provisions governing boards of
trustees of certain school districts; establishing certain
measures for the designation of focus and priority school
districts, sponsors of charter schools and public schools;
revising provisions governing the Commission on School
Funding; revising provisions governing the Early
Childhood Literacy and Readiness Account; revising
provisions governing prekindergarten programs; revising
provisions governing assessments used to assess the
literacy of certain pupils; revising provisions governing
membership of the State Public Charter School Authority;
revising provisions governing the formation of
charter schools, the termination and amendment of charter
-
*SB460_R2*

– 2 –
contracts and the employment of teachers by charter
schools; revising provisions governing the Nevada
Educational Choice Scholarship Program; revising certain
provisions governing instruction in English language arts;
creating the Commission on Recruitment and Retention;
revising provisions relating to the Commission on
Professional Standards in Education; revising provisions
governing background investigations of applicants for
certain licenses; establishing requirements governing the
hiring of a superintendent of schools; revising provisions
governing certain evaluations; requiring the creation of a
differential pay scale for certain teachers and
administrators; creating the Education Service Center;
establishing certain requirements for the Board of Regents
of the University of Nevada; creating certain accounts and
programs concerning teacher apprenticeships; making
appropriations; and providing other matters properly
relating thereto.
Legislative Counsel’s Digest:
1 Existing law establishes the Department of Education, which consists of the
2 State Board of Education and the Superintendent of Public Instruction. (NRS
3 385.010) Existing law: (1) requires the State Board to prepare a plan to improve the
4 academic achievement of pupils; and (2) sets forth the required contents of the plan.
5 (NRS 385.111, 385.112) Existing law also requires the board of trustees of each
6 school district and the governing bodies of certain charter schools to prepare an
7 annual report of accountability that contains certain information, including, without
8 limitation, information regarding teachers, other licensed educational personnel and
9 paraprofessionals. (NRS 385A.070, 385A.230)
10 Section 1.3 of this bill: (1) requires each public elementary school to prepare a
11 plan to improve the academic achievement of pupils enrolled in public elementary
12 schools; (2) sets forth the required contents of the plan, including, without
13 limitation, certain goals for public elementary schools; and (3) establishes
14 requirements governing the consequences for the principal of a public elementary
15 school that does not meet such goals. Sections 4 and 5 of this bill make changes
16 regarding the entity required to prepare such a plan pursuant to existing law.
17 (NRS 385.111)
18 Section 1.7 of this bill establishes a procedure by which the superintendent of
19 schools of a school district or the Superintendent of Public Instruction is authorized
20 to modify, suspend or eliminate a requirement for a public school or school district
21 to report information or data that is redundant or duplicative or does not provide
22 information or data that is used by the Department, the State Board or any other
23 person or entity to support educational outcomes.
24 Existing law creates the Commission on Innovation and Excellence in
25 Education for the purpose of developing a statewide vision and implementation
26 plan to improve public education in this State. (NRS 385.920) Section 5.5 of this
27 bill revises the duties of the Commission.
28 Section 6.1 of this bill requires that the annual report of accountability include
29 information on the plans to improve academic achievement prepared pursuant to
30 existing law and section 1.3. (NRS 385.111) Section 7 of this bill applies certain
31 requirements governing the annual report of accountability to the reporting
-
*SB460_R2*

– 3 –
32 requirements set forth in section 6.1. Section 8 of this bill revises the manner by
33 which teacher vacancies are measured for inclusion in the annual report of
34 accountability.
35 Existing law establishes a statewide system of accountability for public schools
36 that includes, without limitation, a method to annually rate each public school
37 based on the performance of the school and on whether each public school meets
38 the school achievement targets and performance targets established pursuant to the
39 statewide system of accountability. (NRS 385A.600) Sections 6.2-6.4 and 8.5 of
40 this bill establish a similar system of accountability for school districts and charter
41 schools in this State. Section 6.5 of this bill establishes criteria and procedures for
42 the Superintendent to designate a school district or sponsor of a charter school as
43 low-performing or underperforming. Section 9.3 of this bill requires: (1) the
44 Superintendent to place a school district or sponsor of a charter school designated
45 as underperforming on probation if the designation is based on certain findings; and
46 (2) such a school district or sponsor to submit to the Department a school district or
47 sponsor of a charter school performance improvement plan and a school board or
48 sponsor of a charter school improvement plan. Section 9.5 of this bill authorizes the
49 Superintendent to take certain actions if the board of trustees of a school district or
50 sponsor of a charter school does not make adequate progress toward meeting the
51 goals and benchmarks necessary to improve the performance of the school district
52 or charter school. Section 9.7 of this bill requires: (1) the Superintendent to place a
53 school district or sponsor of a charter school designated as underperforming on
54 probation if the designation was based on certain findings relating to the
55 performance of pupils; and (2) such a school district or sponsor to submit certain
56 plans to the Superintendent. Section 9.7 also establishes the actions that the
57 Superintendent is authorized to take if the school district or sponsor of a charter
58 school does not make adequate progress toward improving the performance of
59 pupils.
60 Section 6.6 of this bill establishes criteria for designating a public school as
61 low-performing, and sections 14.25-14.4 of this bill prescribe the actions that may
62 be taken with respect to a public school designated as low-performing or
63 persistently underperforming. Section 14.3 requires the Superintendent to initiate a
64 process for state intervention to implement certain corrective measures for a school
65 that is designated as persistently underperforming. Section 14.35 establishes
66 provisions governing the corrective measure of replacing the principal and key
67 members of the staff of a school. Section 14.4 establishes provisions governing the
68 corrective measure of the direct management of a school by the Department.
69 Section 56.5 of this bill: (1) creates the Education Service Center; (2) provides for
70 the appointment of a governing body for the Center; and (3) requires the Center to
71 provide certain assistance and guidance to public schools and school districts that
72 are experiencing low performance.
73 Section 9.3 requires the Superintendent to place certain underperforming
74 school districts or sponsors of charter schools on probation.
75 Section 84.5 of this bill requires the Legislative Counsel to, in preparing the
76 Nevada Revised Statutes, substitute the term: (1) “focus” for the term “low-
77 performing” as previously used in reference to a low-performing school district,
78 sponsor of a charter school or school; and (2) “priority” for the term
79 “underperforming” as previously used in reference to an underperforming school
80 district or sponsor of a charter school or persistently underperforming school.
81 (NRS 220.120)
82 Existing law provides that, on or before December 31 of each year, the board of
83 trustees of each school district and the State Public Charter School Authority is
84 required to prepare for the immediately preceding school year a report of
85 accountability concerning the educational goals and objectives of the school district
-
*SB460_R2*

– 4 –
86 or charter school. (NRS 385A.070) Sections 7.4 and 7.5 of this bill revise certain
87 provisions governing the report.
88 Existing law: (1) creates county school districts; and (2) provides that such
89 school districts are political subdivisions of this State. (NRS 386.010) Section 9.1
90 of this bill provides for the impaneling of a Public Education Oversight Board
91 under certain circumstances and provides the Board, if impaneled, with the
92 authority granted to the board of trustees of a school district to take actions
93 necessary to remedy the cause of recommendations submitted by the
94 Superintendent of Public Instruction. Section 9.1 additionally sets forth: (1) the
95 membership of the Board; and (2) requirements for meetings of the Board.
96 Existing law: (1) sets forth the membership of the board of trustees in each
97 county school district in which more than 75,000 pupils are enrolled (currently only
98 the Clark County School District); (2) provides that four members of such a board
99 of trustees are appointed, nonvoting members; and (3) sets forth requirements for
100 electing officers of any board of trustees of a school district. (NRS 386.120,
101 386.165, 386.310) Section 10 of this bill: (1) provides that such appointed,
102 nonvoting members are instead voting members; and (2) eliminates the prohibition
103 on the ability of such members to vote for or serve as officers. Section 11 of this
104 bill makes a conforming change to authorize the previously nonvoting members to
105 serve as officers.
106 Existing law creates the Commission on School Funding and establishes the
107 duties of the Commission. (NRS 387.1246, 387.12463) Section 12 of this bill
108 requires the Commission to: (1) review and propose any necessary revisions to the
109 method of calculating the percentage of at-risk pupils in this State; and (2) select a
110 third party to verify such methods and to submit a report containing the findings
111 and recommendations for using a different method. Section 62 of this bill
112 authorizes the Commission to request the drafting of not more than 1 legislative
113 measure for a regular session. Section 63 of this bill applies existing provisions
114 governing the drafting of such measures to the drafting of a legislative measure
115 pursuant to section 62. Section 81 of this bill directs the Commission to conduct an
116 interim study concerning certain subjects relating to school funding.
117 Existing law creates the Early Childhood Literacy and Readiness Account and
118 authorizes the Department to award grants to school districts, sponsors of charter
119 schools and nonprofit organizations to support early childhood literacy and
120 readiness programs. (NRS 387.1271-387.1277) Existing law additionally requires
121 the Department, to the extent money is available, to award grants to school districts,
122 sponsors of charter schools and nonprofit organizations to support prekindergarten
123 programs. (NRS 387.652) Section 13 of this bill: (1) extends eligibility to receive
124 grants to support early childhood literacy and readiness programs to institutions
125 within the Nevada System of Higher Education; and (2) expands the categories of
126 children served by such a program. Section 13.5 of this bill creates similar
127 provisions for grants to support prekindergarten programs.
128 Existing law: (1) requires that the ratio of pupils per licensed teacher in certain
129 classes not exceed certain ratios; and (2) authorizes the State Board to grant a
130 variance to a school district that does not meet such ratios in a quarter of a school
131 year. (NRS 388.700). Section 16 of this bill requires requests for, and reports
132 concerning, variances of requirements for the ratio of pupils per licensed teacher to
133 be submitted annually rather than quarterly. Sections 17 and 18 of this bill make
134 conforming changes to reflect the change to the timelines for such submissions.
135 (NRS 388.723, 388.725)
136 Existing law requires an elementary school to provide intervention services and
137 intensive instruction to a pupil during the time the pupil attends the school if the
138 pupil does not obtain a score in the subject area of reading on the criterion-
139 referenced examination in reading that meets the score prescribed by the State
140 Board. (NRS 388A.487, 392.760) Section 8.3 of this bill requires the statewide
-
*SB460_R2*

– 5 –
141 system of accountability for public schools to include, for elementary schools,
142 targets for the proportion of pupils demonstrating adequate proficiency in the
143 subject area of reading and adequate progress to achieving such proficiency.
144 Existing law requires the board of trustees of a school district or the governing
145 body of a charter school to prepare a plan to improve the literacy of pupils enrolled
146 in an elementary school that includes procedures to assess the proficiency of a pupil
147 in reading by using assessments that have been approved by the State Board. (NRS
148 388.157) Section 15.6 of this bill removes the requirement that such assessments be
149 approved by the State Board thereby allowing the board of trustees of a school
150 district or the governing body of a charter school, as applicable, to include in the
151 plan any valid and reliable standards-based assessment to assess proficiency in
152 reading. This bill also authorizes the Department of Education to: (1) adopt
153 regulations prescribing how the results of any assessment used by a school district
154 or charter school to assess proficiency in reading are collected and reported; and (2)
155 prescribe the assessments which must be used in a school district or charter school
156 if no assessment is included in the plan.
157 Existing law makes certain requirements governing the minimum number of
158 days in a school year. (NRS 388.090) Section 15.5 of this bill requires each school
159 year to contain at least 4 days of professional development for elementary school
160 staff and prescribes the focus of such professional development.
161 Existing law requires a public school, to the extent that money is available, to
162 employ a school counselor on a full-time basis and provide for a comprehensive
163 program for school counseling. (NRS 388.055) Section 15 of this bill requires each
164 public school located in a county whose population is 100,000 or more (currently
165 Clark and Washoe Counties) to provide for the availability of a school counselor or
166 an equivalent service.
167 Existing law creates the State Public Charter School Authority and prescribes
168 the membership of the Authority. (NRS 388A.150, 388A.153) Existing law
169 additionally sets forth the requirements for the process of applying to form a charter
170 school and amending a charter contract. (NRS 388A.243-388A.258, 388A.276,
171 388A.279) Existing law further requires the sponsor of a charter school to submit a
172 report containing certain information to the Department. (NRS 388A.351) Section
173 20 of this bill changes the membership of the Authority. Section 19 of this bill
174 authorizes the board of trustees of certain school districts to object to the placement
175 of a proposed charter school. Sections 21 and 23 of this bill revise certain
176 requirements relating to: (1) the contents of an application to form a charter school;
177 (2) the review of such an application; and (3) a public meeting for the consideration
178 of such an application. Section 25 of this bill requires the Authority to take certain
179 actions regarding a proposed amendment to a charter contract for a charter school it
180 sponsors. Section 26 of this bill requires a report prepared by the sponsor of a
181 charter school to include a description of the expenditures and sources of all
182 revenues for the charter school.
183 Existing law also requires the sponsor of a charter school to terminate the
184 charter contract or restart the charter school under a new charter contract if the
185 charter school receives certain ratings indicating underperformance of the charter
186 school in 3 years out of any 5 consecutive years. (NRS 388A.300) Section 25.3 of
187 this bill: (1) instead provides that the sponsor of a charter school is required to
188 terminate the charter contract or restart the charter school under a new charter
189 contract if the charter school receives certain ratings indicating underperformance
190 of the charter school in 3 consecutive years; and (2) eliminates the prohibition on
191 using the rating of a charter school issued for any school year before the 2015-2016
192 school year for making such a determination. Sections 25.3 and 25.5 of this bill
193 also provide that, until October 1, 2027, the sponsor of such a charter school is not
194 required to terminate the charter contract or restart the charter school under a new
195 charter contract if, pursuant to the statewide system of accountability for public
-
*SB460_R2*

– 6 –
196 schools, the charter school receives certain ratings or increases a rating from the
197 immediately preceding school year by a certain percentage.
198 Existing law requires at least 80 percent of the teachers who provide instruction
199 at a charter school to hold a license or endorsement to teach in this State. (NRS
200 388A.518) Section 28 of this bill instead requires, with certain exceptions, that any
201 teacher who provides instruction at a charter school to hold such a license or
202 endorsement. Section 27 of this bill provides that the governing body of a charter
203 school may adopt rules relating to the truancy of pupils if the rules are not more
204 restrictive than those set forth for pupils enrolled in traditional public schools,
205 thereby removing the authority under existing law for the governing body of a
206 charter school to adopt more restrictive rules relating to the truancy of pupils. (NRS
207 392.130-392.220)
208 Existing law provides that each public school within a school district in this
209 State which has more than 100,000 pupils enrolled in its public schools (currently
210 the Clark County School District) is deemed to be a local school precinct. (NRS
211 388G.530, 388G.600) Under existing law, a local school precinct is required to
212 operate using site-based decision-making in which certain responsibilities are
213 transferred from the large school district to the local school precinct. (NRS
214 388G.600) Section 85 of this bill repeals this authority. Sections 33.2-33.54 and
215 33.9 of this bill make conforming changes to reflect this change. Sections 33.57-
216 33.59 of this bill revise provisions governing certain duties of the superintendent of
217 schools of a large school district.
218 Existing law: (1) authorizes a local school precinct to carry forward its year-end
219 balance to the next school year for use by the local school precinct; and (2) requires
220 a local school precinct that carries forward a balance that exceeds 5 percent of its
221 actual expenditures to use the money for certain purposes. (NRS 388G.650)
222 Section 33.56 of this bill authorizes a large school district to intervene to require a
223 local school precinct to spend any money carried forward for certain purposes.
224 Existing law sets forth requirements governing the involvement of an
225 organizational team for a local school precinct when a vacancy occurs in the
226 position of principal for a local school precinct (NRS 388G.740) Section 33.8 of
227 this bill revises these provisions.
228 Existing law: (1) creates the Nevada Educational Choice Scholarship Program;
229 (2) establishes requirements for a scholarship organization that provides grants on
230 behalf of a pupil to a school in which the pupil is enrolled; and (3) requires such a
231 scholarship organization to submit an annual report to the Department containing
232 certain information. (NRS 388D.250-388D.280) Section 30 of this bill establishes
233 certain reporting requirements for schools that receive such grants. Section 31 of
234 this bill requires such schools to administer certain examinations and assessments
235 to certain pupils. Section 33 of this bill requires each school that receives such a
236 grant to comply with the provisions of sections 30 and 31. Section 32 of this bill
237 applies the definition of “scholarship organization” in existing law to sections 30-
238 31.7 of this bill. (NRS 388D.260)
239 Existing regulations include provisions governing the operation of the Nevada
240 Educational Choice Scholarship Program. (NAC 388D.030-388D.130) Sections
241 31.2-31.7 codify certain provisions of these regulations into the Nevada Revised
242 Statutes. Section 31.2 requires a scholarship organization to register with the
243 Department by submitting certain information. Section 31.3 requires: (1) a
244 registered scholarship organization to provide to the Department certain
245 information concerning each pupil on behalf of whom it awards a grant; and (2) the
246 Department to compile certain information submitted by each scholarship
247 organization and review the information to determine whether to recommend a
248 change to the Legislature in the priority for awarding grants. Section 31.5 requires
249 a registered scholarship organization to notify the Department of Taxation of each
250 donation received and prohibits a scholarship organization from carrying forward a
-
*SB460_R2*

– 7 –
251 donation for more than 5 years. Section 31.6 requires the Department of Education
252 to: (1) maintain a directory of each scholarship organization registered with the
253 Department; (2) submit a list of scholarship organizations registered with the
254 Department to the Department of Taxation each quarter; and (3) submit a summary
255 of certain reports made to the Department of Education to certain entities annually.
256 Section 31.7 authorizes the parent or guardian of a pupil to apply directly to a
257 scholarship organization for a grant and establishes the order of priority in which
258 a scholarship organization is required to award grants. Section 31.7 also requires a
259 scholarship organization to establish written procedures for determining whether a
260 pupil is qualified to receive a grant and awarding grants on behalf of pupils.
261 Section 31.8 of this bill adds sections 31.2-31.7 to the provisions that may be cited
262 as the Nevada Educational Choice Scholarship Program.
263 Existing law requires the Department to adopt regulations prescribing certain
264 limitations on: (1) the time taken from instruction to conduct an examination or
265 assessment; and (2) the number of examinations or assessments administered in a
266 school year. (NRS 390.805) Section 35 of this bill establishes additional
267 requirements for such regulations. Section 34 of this bill sets forth certain reporting
268 requirements concerning the amount of class time used to prepare for and conduct
269 examinations and assessments.
270 Sections 37 and 38 of this bill: (1) create the Commission on Recruitment and
271 Retention within the Department; (2) set forth the membership and duties of the
272 Commission; and (3) require the Commission to study issues relating to the
273 recruitment and retention of educators in this State. Section 85 of this bill repeals
274 provisions governing the Nevada State Teacher and Education Support Professional
275 Recruitment and Retention Advisory Task Force, thereby dissolving the Task
276 Force. (NRS 391.486-391.496)
277 Existing law creates the Commission on Professional Standards in Education
278 and requires the Commission to prescribe regulations, subject to approval by the
279 State Board, for licensing teachers and other educational personnel. (NRS 391.011,
280 391.019, 391.027) Section 39 of this bill requires the Commission to establish
281 requirements for a person to obtain a provisional license with an endorsement as a
282 registered apprentice. Section 85 repeals the authorization for the State Board to
283 disapprove any regulation adopted by the Commission. Sections 39-42 of this bill
284 make conforming changes to reflect the repeal of authority granted to the State
285 Board. Section 41 revises provisions governing the timing and content of certain
286 reports submitted by the Commission. (NRS 391.028) Section 44 of this bill
287 requires the Department, rather than the State Board, to annually evaluate each
288 provider approved by the Commission to offer certain courses of study or training.
289 (NRS 391.039) Section 48 of this bill eliminates the requirement that certain
290 reports concerning a shortage of teachers be submitted to the State Board.
291 (NRS 391.125)
292 Existing law: (1) authorizes certain entities, including, without limitation, a city
293 or county, to sponsor charter schools; and (2) prohibits a city or county from
294 sponsoring a new charter school or expanding the enrollment or operating an
295 additional campus of an existing charter school sponsored by the city or county if
296 the total number of pupils enrolled in the charter schools sponsored by the city or
297 county exceeds a certain percentage of the pupils enrolled in public schools in the
298 city or county other than in charter schools not sponsored by the city or county.
299 (NRS 388A.220) Section 20.5 of this bill creates an exception to this prohibition by
300 authorizing a city or county to sponsor a new charter school or expand the
301 enrollment or operate an additional campus of an existing charter school sponsored
302 by the city or county, regardless of the number of pupils that will be enrolled in the
303 charter schools sponsored by the city or county, if certain conditions are met.
304 Existing law: (1) designates certain academic subjects, including English
305 language arts, as core academic subjects that must be taught in all public schools;
-
*SB460_R2*

– 8 –
306 and (2) requires the Council to Establish Academic Standards for Public Schools to
307 adopt standards of content and performance for certain courses of study, including
308 courses in the core academic subjects. (NRS 389.018, 389.520) Section 33.97 of
309 this bill makes certain requirements governing the standards and instruction for
310 English language arts. Section 33.93 of this bill requires the Department, to the
311 extent that money is available for such a purpose, to establish a pilot program under
312 which schools or groups of schools may apply to the Department for grants to
313 integrate science, technology, engineering and mathematics into instruction in

315 pilot program to determine whether model curriculum for English language arts

317 engineering and mathematics into English language arts in kindergarten and grades
318 1, 2 and 3.
319 Section 38.2 of this bill provides that a school employee is immune from civil
320 and criminal liability for actions taken in good faith to intervene in physical
321 altercations, fights or other incidents that pose an imminent risk to the safety of
322 pupils or other school employees if: (1) the school employee is acting within the
323 course and scope of his or her employment and within the course and scope of his
324 or her role in maintaining order, discipline or the safety of pupils; (2) the actions of
325 the school employee are consistent with state, federal and local laws and the
326 policies of the school district or school at which the school employee is employed;
327 and (3) any harm caused by the intervention is not the result of intentional, willful,
328 grossly negligent or reckless misconduct or a conscious and flagrant indifference to
329 the rights or safety of the person harmed. Section 58.7 of this bill applies this
330 immunity from civil and criminal liability to employees of private schools.
331 Existing law requires the Commission on Professional Standards in Education
332 to adopt regulations prescribing the qualifications for licensing teachers and other
333 educational personnel. (NRS 391.019, 391.021) Under existing regulations, a
334 license to teach elementary education authorizes the holder to teach all subjects in
335 elementary grades. (NAC 391.090) Sections 39, 41.5 and 41.6 of this bill require
336 the Commission to adopt regulations requiring that, to be eligible to teach pupils in
337 kindergarten or grade 1, 2 or 3 on or after July 1, 2028, a teacher is required to
338 obtain an endorsement to teach such pupils by successfully completing a course of
339 instruction in foundational literacy skills that is approved by the Commission and
340 meets certain standards. Section 59.5 of this bill authorizes the Board of Regents of
341 the University of Nevada to require certain institutions within the Nevada System
342 of Higher Education to collaborate with the Department and the Commission to
343 establish such courses.
344 Existing law requires a postprobationary employee of a school district whose
345 performance is designated as developing or ineffective for 2 consecutive years to
346 serve an additional probationary period. (NRS 391.730) Under existing law: (1) a
347 period of probation is for three 1-year periods and a probationary employee has no
348 right to employment after any of the three probationary contract years; and (2)
349 during the contract year, the probationary employee may be dismissed after
350 receiving notice and an opportunity for a hearing. (NRS 391.820-391.826) Section
351 52.5 of this bill provides that if a postprobationary employee is serving an
352 additional probationary period under existing law and the postprobationary
353 employee receives a rating of ineffective for 2 consecutive years during that
354 additional probationary period: (1) the board of trustees of the school district may
355 notify the employee that the employee may not be reemployed for the next contract
356 year; or (2) the superintendent of the school district may initiate the process of
357 dismissing the employee during a contract year. Under section 52.5, if a school
358 district does not reemploy or dismisses such an employee, the Department is
359 required to provide: (1) the school district with certain assistance in recruiting and
360 hiring a highly effective administrator to fill any vacancy created; and (2) school
-
*SB460_R2*

– 9 –
361 leadership with access to certain coaching to assist the school leadership in
362 managing transitions and improving teaching practices.
363 Section 38.8 of this bill authorizes a postprobationary teacher to be placed on a
364 period of probation of 2 school years if certain conditions are met. If a
365 postprobationary teacher is placed on such a period of probation, a performance
366 improvement plan must be established for the postprobationary teacher pursuant to
367 section 38.7 of this bill. Under section 38.8, at the conclusion of the period of
368 probation pursuant to that section, the postprobationary teacher must be evaluated.
369 If, based on that evaluation, the teacher has not made adequate progress toward
370 meeting improvement goals, section 38.8 authorizes the teacher to not be
371 reemployed or to be dismissed in the same manner as a probationary employee.
372 Sections 38.3 and 38.4 of this bill enact provisions for administrators similar to
373 sections 38.7 and 38.8. Section 38.6 of this bill requires the Department to track
374 certain data relating to the effectiveness of programs that provide training for
375 school administrators, assess the effectiveness of such programs and make
376 recommendations for the improvement of such programs.
377 Existing law requires the board of trustees of each school district and the
378 governing body of each charter school to ensure that teachers employed by the
379 school district or charter school have access to certain professional development
380 training. (NRS 391A.370) Section 56.2 of this bill requires the board of trustees of

382 teachers who teach pupils in kindergarten and grades 1, 2 and 3, administrators of

386 Existing law requires an applicant for the issuance or renewal of a license as a
387 teacher or other educational personnel position to submit to the Superintendent of
388 Public Instruction a complete set of his or her fingerprints and written permission
389 authorizing the Superintendent to forward the fingerprints to the Central Repository
390 for Nevada Records of Criminal History for its report on the criminal history of the
391 applicant and for submission to the Federal Bureau of Investigation (hereinafter
392 “FBI”) for its report on the criminal history of the applicant. (NRS 179A.075,
393 391.033) Sections 43 and 61 of this bill remove the requirement for an applicant
394 for the renewal of a license as a teacher or other educational personnel to submit to
395 the Superintendent a complete set of fingerprints for the purpose of obtaining a
396 report on the criminal history of the applicant. Instead, section 60 of this bill
397 authorizes the Central Repository and the Department of Education to participate in
398 the in the Rap Back Program administered by the Federal Bureau of Investigation
399 (FBI) for the purpose of enabling the Department to obtain ongoing status
400 notifications of any criminal history of a person licensed by the Superintendent.
401 Under section 60: (1) any fingerprints submitted by an applicant for the issuance of
402 a license as a teacher or other educational personnel will be retained in certain
403 systems maintained by the Central Repository and the FBI for the purposes of the
404 Rap Back Program; and (2) the Central Repository must establish certain methods
405 of handling such fingerprints. Section 60 further provides for the confidentiality of
406 such criminal history information and the destruction of fingerprints maintained in
407 the system when a person is no longer licensed. Section 60 additionally requires the
408 Department to obtain consent from a person before submitting his or her
409 fingerprints to the Central Repository and the FBI. Under section 83, persons who
410 are licensed by the Superintendent at the time the Rap Back Program becomes
411 effective are required to submit fingerprints for the purposes of the Program at the
412 time of the first renewal of their license after the Program is effective and would
413 not submit fingerprints for subsequent renewals. Section 45 of this bill makes a
414 conforming change related to fees for the renewal of such a license to reflect that
415 fingerprints for a background check would no longer be submitted with a renewal
-
*SB460_R2*

– 10 –
416 application when the Rap Back Program becomes effective. (NRS 391.040)
417 Section 46 of this bill makes a conforming change to remove a requirement for a
418 person who is licensed by the Superintendent and who is returned to employment
419 after certain leave to submit fingerprints for the purposes of a background check
420 because the Department would be receiving notifications for such purposes through
421 the Rap Back Program. (NRS 391.104)
422 The board of trustees of a school district is authorized to employ a
423 superintendent of schools. (NRS 391.110) Section 47 of this bill requires the board
424 of trustees of a school district located in a county whose population is 100,000 or

426 when hiring a superintendent of schools.

20 Sec. 1.7. 1. It is the intent of the Legislature to:
21 (a) Enhance the efficiency of education reporting
22 requirements by eliminating the reporting of redundant
23 information and data, reducing administrative burdens and
24 ensuring that all reports serve a meaningful purpose in supporting
25 educational outcomes.
26 (b) Ensure that teachers and school administrators, who are
27 directly impacted by reporting requirements, have agency in
28 recommending modifications to reporting requirements.
29 (c) Preserve transparency, the accountability of public schools
30 and school districts for the quality of schools and the educational
31 achievement of pupils, and the accessibility of information and
32 data concerning the educational achievement of pupils.
33 2. A teacher or school administrator employed at a public
34 school, a charter management organization that operates a
35 charter school or an educational management organization that
36 provides support or operations to a charter school may submit a
37 petition to modify, suspend or eliminate a requirement for a public
38 school or school district to report information or data to another
39 person or entity. Such a petition must be submitted to the
40 superintendent of schools of the school district in which the public
41 school is located or, if the public school is a charter school, the
42 governing body of the charter school. The petition must:
43 (a) Clearly identify the requirement to report information or
44 data that the petitioner is seeking to modify, suspend or eliminate;
-
*SB460_R2*

– 14 –
1 (b) Contain a detailed explanation of the reason that the
2 requirement to report information or data is duplicative or
3 redundant or does not provide information or data that is used by
4 the Department, the State Board or any other person or entity to
5 support educational outcomes; and
6 (c) Propose an alternative report of information or data, if any,
7 that would ensure that information and data to support
8 educational outcomes remains accessible.
9 3. Upon receipt of a petition submitted pursuant to subsection
10 2, the superintendent of schools of the school district or governing
11 body of the charter school, as applicable, shall:
12 (a) Review the petition to determine whether the requirement
13 to report data or information that is proposed for modification,
14 suspension or elimination is duplicative or redundant or does not
15 provide data or information that is used by the Department, the
16 State Board or any other person or entity to support educational
17 outcomes.
18 (b) If the petition requests to modify, suspend or eliminate a
19 requirement for a public school to report data or information to
20 the school district and the superintendent of schools of the school
21 district finds that the requirement to report data or information
22 proposed for modification, suspension or elimination is duplicative
23 or redundant or does not provide data that is used by the school
24 district to support educational outcomes, approve the petition and
25 issue a decision modifying, eliminating or suspending the
26 requirement. If the superintendent of schools of the school district
27 issues such a decision, the superintendent shall provide notice of
28 the approval of the petition to the petitioner, each public school
29 within the school district and any other person or entity affected
30 by the modification, suspension or elimination of the reporting
31 requirement. If the superintendent of public schools of the school
32 district denies a petition to modify, suspend or eliminate a
33 requirement for a public school to report data or information to
34 the school district, the superintendent shall provide a written
35 explanation of the reasons for the denial to the petitioner. A

37 submit a request for reconsideration of the denial to the
38 superintendent of schools of the school district or resubmit the
39 petition with additional information.
40 (c) If the petition requests to modify, suspend or eliminate a
41 requirement for a public school or the school district to report data
42 or information to any person or entity other than the school
43 district and the superintendent of schools of the school district
44 finds that the requirement to report data or information proposed
45 for modification, suspension or elimination is duplicative or
-

8 Sec. 6.2. 1. The Department shall make every effort to

10 schools applies uniformly to all school districts and charter
11 schools in this State and complies with all requirements for the
12 accountability of public schools, including, without limitation,
13 requirements for the receipt of federal money under the

19 provided in subsection 3 of section 6.4 of this act:
20 (a) Include a method to, on an annual basis, rate each school
21 district and sponsor of a charter school based upon the collective
22 performance of the public schools within the school district or the
23 charter schools sponsored by the sponsor, as applicable, and the
24 achievement of district-wide or sponsor-wide performance targets,
25 as applicable, established pursuant to the statewide system of
26 accountability for public schools;
27 (b) Include a method to implement consequences, rewards,
28 supports and interventions for school districts and sponsors of
29 charter schools based upon such ratings, with a focus on
30 addressing disparities and improving outcomes for historically
31 underserved populations;

33 other resources, to the extent that money is available for that
34 purpose, to school districts or sponsors of charter schools
35 receiving one of the two lowest ratings of performance pursuant to
36 the statewide system of accountability for public schools; and

35 section 9.1 of this act before implementation.
36 Sec. 6.5. 1. The Superintendent of Public Instruction:
37 (a) Shall designate a school district or sponsor of a charter
38 school as a low-performing school district or sponsor of a charter
39 school if:
40 (1) The Department has determined that the school district
41 or sponsor of the charter school has failed to meet the district-wide
42 or sponsor-wide achievement targets and performance targets, as
43 applicable, established pursuant to the statewide system of
44 accountability for public schools; or
-
*SB460_R2*

– 32 –
1 (2) The school district or sponsor of the charter school
2 receives one of the two lowest ratings of performance pursuant to
3 the statewide system of accountability for public schools.
4 (b) May designate a school district or sponsor of a charter
5 school as a low-performing school district or sponsor of a charter
6 school if:
7 (1) The administration of the school district or the sponsor
8 of the charter school is characterized by instability or
9 unsatisfactory performance in leadership, including, without
10 limitation, a dismissal, resignation or removal of the
11 superintendent of schools of the school district, that has a
12 significant impact on the operations of the school district or the
13 sponsor of the charter school and the educational outcomes for
14 pupils;
15 (2) The resignation or removal of members of the board of
16 trustees of the school district or the sponsor of the charter school
17 results in multiple vacancies that disrupt the continuity of
18 leadership of the school district or the sponsor of the charter
19 school and impacts the ability of the board of trustees to effectively
20 govern the school district or charter school;
21 (3) The school district or sponsor of the charter school
22 experiences an unexpected and severe financial hardship,
23 including, without limitation, a financial hardship resulting from
24 financial malfeasance, financial mismanagement or any other
25 condition, that threatens the fiscal stability and operational
26 capacity of the school district or sponsor of the charter school; or
27 (4) Based on data and information concerning the
28 achievement and performance of pupils enrolled in public schools
29 in the school district or sponsored by the sponsor of charter
30 schools, the allocation of resources by the school district or the
31 sponsor of the charter school or the availability of educational
32 programs among public schools in the school district or sponsored
33 by the sponsor of charter schools and specific groups of pupils
34 enrolled in those schools, the school district or sponsor of the
35 charter school is characterized by systemic inequity in educational
36 access, resources or outcomes among specific groups of pupils,
37 including, without limitation, among pupils who are economically
38 disadvantaged, pupils from major racial and ethnic groups, pupils
39 with disabilities and pupils who are English learners.
40 (c) May designate a school district or sponsor of a charter
41 school as a low-performing school district or sponsor of a charter
42 school if a state of emergency for the school district or sponsor of
43 the charter school is declared. Such a state of emergency may be
44 declared if:
-
*SB460_R2*

– 33 –
1 (1) The Governor, the State Board or the Chair of the
2 Legislative Commission issues a written complaint to the board of
3 trustees of a school district or the sponsor of a charter school that
4 identifies a material noncompliance with any state law by the
5 board of trustees of the school district or the sponsor of the charter
6 school;
7 (2) The board of trustees of the school district or the
8 sponsor of the charter school does not provide a satisfactory plan
9 of correction within 60 days after receiving the written complaint;
10 (3) After the time to provide a plan of correction has
11 elapsed, the State Board finds the school district or sponsor of the
12 charter school has engaged in a material noncompliance with
13 state law and votes to recommend impaneling the Public
14 Education Oversight Board pursuant to section 9.1 of this act; and
15 (4) The Superintendent of Public Instruction formally
16 declares a state of emergency, specifying:
17 (I) The actions that failed to comply with state law;
18 (II) The date of the first meeting of the Public
19 Education Oversight Board, which must occur not later than 30
20 days after the declaration of a state of emergency;
21 (III) The date on which the state of emergency
22 terminates, which must occur not later than 90 days after the state
23 of emergency is declared; and
24 (IV) That the state of emergency may be extended for an
25 additional 90 days if a majority of members of the Public
26 Education Oversight Board vote to do so.
27 2. The Superintendent of Public Instruction shall designate a
28 school district or sponsor of a charter school as an
29 underperforming school district or sponsor of a charter school if:
30 (a) For at least 2 consecutive school years, the Superintendent
31 has designated the school district or sponsor of the charter school

33 pursuant to subsection 1; or
34 (b) The Superintendent:
35 (1) Designated the school district or sponsor of the charter
36 school as a low-performing school district or sponsor of a charter
37 school pursuant to subsection 1 in the current or the immediately
38 preceding school year; and
39 (2) Determines that one or more of the conditions set forth
40 in paragraph (b) of subsection 1 exist for the school district or
41 sponsor of the charter school.
42 3. Upon designating a school district or sponsor of a charter

45 specific tiered interventions consistent with the statewide system of

4 Sec. 6.6. 1. The Superintendent of Public Instruction shall
5 designate a public school, other than a public school approved by
6 the State Board to be rated using the alternative performance
7 framework prescribed by the State Board pursuant to NRS
8 385A.730, as a low-performing school if, in at least 2 of the
9 immediately preceding 3 school years, at least one of the following
10 criteria apply to the public school:
11 (a) The public school receives one of the two lowest ratings of
12 performance pursuant to the statewide system of accountability for
13 public schools.
14 (b) The pupils enrolled in the public school demonstrate
15 proficiency in English language arts and mathematics in the
16 bottom 20th percentile of statewide performance metrics, as
17 determined by the Department.
18 (c) For high schools, the average graduation rate is less than
19 60 percent for the immediately preceding 3 school years or less
20 than 70 percent for the immediately preceding 5 school years.
21 (d) For elementary schools, more than 50 percent of the pupils
22 enrolled in the elementary school do not achieve adequate
23 proficiency in the subject area of reading before the completion of
24 grade 3.
25 2. On the day that the Department posts on the Internet
26 website maintained by the Department the determinations and
27 final ratings made for all public schools in this State pursuant to
28 NRS 385A.720:
29 (a) The Department shall post on the Internet website
30 maintained by the Department a list of public schools that are
31 designated as low-performing schools pursuant to subsection 1;
32 (b) Each school district or sponsor of a charter school with at
33 least one public school in the school district or charter school on
34 the list of public schools that are designated as low-performing
35 schools pursuant to subsection 1 shall post the list on the Internet
36 website maintained by the school district or sponsor of the charter
37 school, as applicable; and
38 (c) The Department shall provide the list of public schools that
39 are designated as low-performing schools pursuant to subsection 1
40 to the State Board as part of the report of data provided to the
41 State Board pursuant to subsection 3 of NRS 385A.080.
42 3. The principal of each public school designated as a low-
43 performing school shall notify the parents and legal guardians of
44 pupils enrolled in the public school of the designation of the
45 public school as a low-performing school and the actions that will
-
*SB460_R2*

– 35 –
1 be taken to address the areas of deficiency that caused the
2 designation. The notice must:
3 (a) Contain a summary of the data and information
4 concerning the performance of pupils enrolled in the public
5 school and the specific areas identified for improvement;
6 (b) Provide information on any available support or resources
7 for pupils and their families, including, without limitation,
8 academic and social-emotional resources;
9 (c) Contain a detailed improvement plan outlining the
10 measures the public school intends to implement, with clearly

12 (d) Provide information on alternative educational options
13 available to pupils residing in the zone of attendance of the public

10 Sec. 14.25. 1. The Superintendent of Public Instruction
11 shall place on probation each public school that has been
12 designated as a low-performing school pursuant to subsection 1 of
13 section 6.6 of this act. A period of probation imposed pursuant to
14 this section:
15 (a) Begins on the first day of the first school year following the
16 date of the designation of the public school as a low-performing
17 school; and
18 (b) Must end on the date on which the Department posts a
19 final rating of the public school made pursuant to NRS 385A.720
20 that the Superintendent of Public Instruction determines to
21 indicate that the public school no longer qualifies for designation
22 as a low-performing school pursuant to subsection 1 of section 6.6
23 of this act.
24 2. Not later than 60 days after the beginning of a period of
25 probation imposed pursuant to subsection 1, the principal of the
26 public school shall prepare and submit to the Department a school
27 improvement plan that is based on the plan to improve the
28 academic achievement of pupils prepared pursuant to section 1.3
29 of this act. The school improvement plan must include, without
30 limitation:
31 (a) Specific achievement targets and performance targets to
32 address the reason that the public school was designated as a low-
33 performing school;
34 (b) A clear timeline for implementing any changes to address
35 the reason that the public school was designated as a low-
36 performing school; and
37 (c) A strategic plan for improving pupil outcomes.
38 3. The Superintendent of Public Instruction shall, not later
39 than 30 days after receiving a school improvement plan submitted
40 to the Department pursuant to subsection 2, review and approve or
41 deny approval of the school improvement plan. If the
42 Superintendent of Public Instruction denies approval of the school
43 improvement plan, the Superintendent shall notify the principal of
44 the public school of the reasons for denying approval of the plan.
45 Not later than 30 days after receiving such notice, the principal
-
*SB460_R2*

– 70 –
1 shall prepare and submit to the Department revisions to the school
2 improvement plan. The public school shall implement a school
3 improvement plan approved by the Superintendent of Public
4 Instruction and post the approved school improvement plan on the
5 Internet website maintained by the public school.
6 4. The Superintendent of Public Instruction may appoint an
7 independent school improvement official to oversee the progress of
8 a public school during a period of probation imposed pursuant to
9 this section. An independent school improvement official:
10 (a) Must not have any conflict of interest that may affect his or
11 her ability to monitor objectively the school improvement plan of
12 the public school;
13 (b) Must possess a background in evaluating school
14 improvement practices, assessing effective school strategies and
15 supporting the development of school improvement plans; and

20 by the Superintendent before the appointment of the independent

36 the corrective measure.

41 determine the appropriate next steps. Based on this review, the
42 Superintendent shall recommend to the Public Education
43 Oversight Board one of the following actions:
44 (a) Renew the corrective measure for an additional term of not
45 more than 10 years, if the public school has demonstrated

1 sustained progress but has not met or exceeded its achievement

8 Sec. 14.4. 1. If, pursuant to section 14.3 of this act, the
9 corrective measure of direct management of the public school by
10 the Department is approved by the Public Education Oversight

13 underperforming, the Superintendent of Public Instruction shall

15 school.
16 2. If the Superintendent of Public Instruction assumes
17 responsibility for overseeing the operations of a public school
18 pursuant to subsection 1, the Superintendent shall appoint a
19 school turnaround director to manage the public school. The
20 school turnaround director shall:
21 (a) Exercise full operational control of the public school,
22 including, without limitation:
23 (1) Overseeing all instructional, operational and financial
24 decisions;
25 (2) Implementing personnel decisions, including, without
26 limitation, the hiring, reassignment or replacement of
27 administrators, teachers and other staff employed at the public
28 school in compliance with state and federal law; and
29 (3) Revising curriculum and instructional strategies to
30 align with best practices for improving pupil outcomes.
31 (b) Develop and implement a comprehensive school
32 turnaround plan. The school turnaround plan must include,
33 without limitation:
34 (1) Specific academic and operational benchmarks the
35 public school must meet during the period of the corrective
36 measure imposed pursuant to this section;
37 (2) Evidence-based interventions to address areas of
38 underperformance;
39 (3) Strategies to close achievement gaps for underserved
40 populations of pupils, including, without limitation, pupils with
41 special needs, low-income pupils, pupils who are English learners
42 and pupils from diverse racial or ethnic backgrounds;
43 (4) A detailed timeline for achieving measurable progress
44 in performance; and
-
*SB460_R2*

– 78 –
1 (5) An evaluation of policies prescribed by the school
2 district to identify any waivers necessary for the effective execution
3 of the school turnaround plan.

5 district or sponsor of the charter school and submit the proposed
6 waivers to the superintendent of schools of the school district or
7 the sponsor of the charter school, as applicable, for review and to
8 the Superintendent of Public Instruction for review and approval.
9 (d) Provide regular updates to the Superintendent of Public
10 Instruction, the Public Education Oversight Board and the board
11 of trustees of the school district or the sponsor of the charter
12 school on the implementation of the school turnaround plan to
13 ensure transparency and accountability.

21 (a) Establish written procedures that the scholarship
22 organization will use to determine whether a pupil meets the

24 award grants on behalf of pupils.

27 and provide a written copy of the procedures with each application
28 form.
29 (c) Provide an application form to be completed by an
30 applicant for a grant. A scholarship organization may only award
31 a grant on behalf of a pupil for whom a complete application is
32 submitted but is not required to award a grant to a pupil solely
33 because his or her application is complete.
34 (d) Verify annually that each pupil on behalf of whom the
35 scholarship organization awards a grant is a member of a
36 household that has a household income which is not more than
37 300 percent of the federally designated level signifying poverty.
38 Such verification must:
39 (1) Use the most recent federal poverty guidelines published
40 in the Federal Register by the United States Department of Health
41 and Human Services; and
42 (2) Calculate household income based on the information
43 reported in the application submitted on behalf of the pupil and in

45 and Nutrition Service of the United States Department of
-
*SB460_R2*

– 108 –
1 Agriculture for determining eligibility of pupils for free and
2 reduced-price meals.
3 3. A scholarship organization shall award grants on behalf of
4 pupils in the following order of priority:
5 (a) A grant must be awarded for the current school year on
6 behalf of a pupil for whom a completed application was received
7 on or before the deadline for the submission of such applications
8 by the scholarship organization and on whose behalf a grant was
9 awarded for the immediately preceding school year before a grant
10 is awarded on behalf of any other pupil.
11 (b) A grant must be awarded on behalf of a pupil for whom a
12 completed application was received on or before the deadline for
13 the submission of such applications by the scholarship
14 organization and who is the sibling of a pupil on whose behalf a
15 grant has been awarded for the current school year before a grant
16 is awarded on behalf of other pupils.
17 (c) A grant must be awarded on behalf of a pupil who is not
18 described in paragraph (a) or (b) in the order in which the
19 completed application is received. If there are an insufficient
20 number of grants available to award a grant on behalf of each
21 pupil for whom a complete application was received on the same
22 day:
23 (1) A grant must be awarded on behalf of a pupil who is a
24 member of a household that has a lower household income before
25 a grant is awarded on behalf of a pupil who is a member of a
26 household that has a higher household income;
27 (2) If two or more applicants are members of households
28 that have the same household income, a grant must be awarded on
29 behalf of the pupil who is enrolled in a public school that has
30 received a lower rating based on the most recent annual report of
31 the statewide system of accountability for public schools before a
32 grant is awarded on behalf of a pupil who is enrolled in a public
33 school that has received higher ratings; and
34 (3) If two or more applicants are members of households
35 that have the same household income and attend public schools
36 that received the same rating based on the most recent annual
37 report of the statewide system of accountability for public schools,
38 grants must be awarded on behalf of pupils in this category on a
39 random basis.
