29 Sec. 33.1. Chapter 388G of NRS is hereby amended by adding
30 thereto a new section to read as follows:
31 1. Beginning July 1, 2026, the board of trustees of a school
32 district may establish a pilot program to designate a public school
33 within the school district as an innovation school. The State
34 Public Charter School Authority may designate a charter school
35 sponsored by the Authority as an innovation school. The purpose
36 of an innovation school is to implement innovative educational
37 practices designed to improve pupil achievement, increase
38 educational equity and address specific challenges within the
39 public school or community it serves.
40 2. A public school may be designated as an innovation school
41 only if:
42 (a) At least 25 percent of the staff assigned to the public school
43 express interest in the designation;
44 (b) More than 50 percent of the staff assigned to the public
45 school vote in favor of the designation; and
-
*SB460_R2*

– 112 –
1 (c) Any collective bargaining rights and agreements remain in
2 effect after the designation.
3 3. To be designated as an innovation school, a public school
4 must develop an innovation plan that:
5 (a) Identifies specific challenges or barriers to pupil
6 achievement and proposes evidence-based strategies to address
7 those challenges or barriers;
8 (b) Outlines measurable goals and performance benchmarks;
9 (c) Details the autonomies requested, including, without
10 limitation, autonomy in any or all of the following:
11 (1) Curriculum;
12 (2) Budgeting;
13 (3) Staffing;
14 (4) Scheduling; or
15 (5) Professional development; and
16 (d) Describes methods for engaging stakeholders, including,
17 without limitation, teachers, parents and community members in
18 the development and implementation of the innovation plan.
19 4. A public school that has developed an innovation plan
20 pursuant to subsection 3 shall submit the innovation plan to the
21 board of trustees of the school district or the State Public Charter
22 School Authority, as applicable. The board of trustees or State
23 Public Charter School Authority shall review the plan and, if the
24 plan is satisfactory, designate the public school as an innovation
25 school.
26 5. The board of trustees or State Public Charter School
27 Authority, as applicable, shall subject an innovation school to
28 heightened measures of accountability to ensure that the proposed
29 innovations lead to measurable improvements in pupil outcomes.
30 An innovation school shall provide to the entity that designated the
31 innovation school an annual progress report that includes,
32 without limitation:
33 (a) Performance of pupils on standardized assessments and
34 other academic benchmarks;
35 (b) Progress toward goals specified in the innovation plan; and
36 (c) Stakeholder engagement and satisfaction metrics.
37 6. The Department may revoke the designation of an
38 innovation school if the innovation school fails to meet the
39 performance benchmarks outlined in its innovation plan or does
40 not comply with applicable laws and regulations.
41 7. A group of innovation schools serving geographically
42 proximate or thematically aligned populations of pupils may be
43 designated as an innovation zone by the board of trustees of a
44 school district or the State Public Charter School Authority, as
45 applicable. The innovation schools within an innovation zone may
-
*SB460_R2*

– 113 –
1 collaborate on shared goals, resources and strategies while
2 maintaining school-level autonomy as outlined in their respective
3 innovation plans.
4 8. The board of trustees of a school district or the sponsor of
5 a charter school, as applicable, shall ensure that an innovation
6 school has access to adequate resources to implement effectively
7 its innovation plan. A pilot innovation school may apply for grants
8 or other funding opportunities provided by the State or the Federal
9 Government to support innovative educational practices.
10 9. The pilot innovation school program established pursuant
11 to this section may include:
12 (a) Not more than three pilot innovation schools in each
13 county whose population is 100,000 or more.
14 (b) Not more than one pilot innovation school in each county
15 whose population is less than 100,000.
16 10. The Department shall adopt regulations prescribing the
17 method for reviewing and approving a pilot innovation school
18 pursuant to subsection 3.

3 Sec. 33.93. Chapter 389 of NRS is hereby amended by adding
4 thereto a new section to read as follows:
5 1. To the extent that money is available, the Department shall
6 establish a pilot program pursuant to which schools selected to
7 participate in the pilot program integrate science, technology,
8 engineering and mathematics into instruction in literacy in
9 kindergarten and grades 1, 2 and 3.
10 2. To carry out the pilot program, the Department shall issue
11 a request for proposals from schools or groups of schools to apply
12 for a grant of money to integrate science, technology, engineering
13 and mathematics into instruction in literacy in kindergarten and
14 grades 1, 2 and 3. In response to such a request for proposals, a
15 school or group of schools may apply to the Department for such a
16 grant.
17 3. In determining whether to approve an application for a
18 grant submitted pursuant to subsection 2, the Department shall
19 consider:
20 (a) The quality of the proposed curricula for a program that
21 integrates texts related to science, technology, engineering and
22 mathematics into instruction in literacy in kindergarten and
23 grades 1, 2 and 3 that uses scientifically based reading research;
24 (b) The proposed instructional strategies; and
25 (c) The extent to which the approach to instruction is
26 innovative.
27 4. Not later than June 1 of the year following the
28 implementation of the pilot program, a school or group of schools
29 receiving a grant of money under the pilot program shall submit to
30 the Department a report that summarizes:
31 (a) The initial outcomes of the use of the grant received from
32 the pilot program, including, without limitation, measurable
33 progress of the foundational literacy skills of pupils;
34 (b) Feedback from teachers and administrators at the school
35 or group of schools who participated in the pilot program; and
36 (c) Recommendations for the integration of science,
37 technology, engineering and mathematics into instruction in
38 literacy in kindergarten and grades 1, 2 and 3 throughout this
39 State.
40 5. The Department shall present the findings of the pilot
41 program to the State Board, and the Department shall determine
42 whether to:
43 (a) Extend the pilot program for an additional year;
44 (b) Expand the pilot program to additional schools; or
45 (c) Discontinue the pilot program.
-
*SB460_R2*

– 122 –
1 6. As used in this section, “scientifically based reading
2 research” means research that employs rigorous, systematic and
3 objective:
4 (a) Methods to gain knowledge from multiple disciplines to
5 understand how children learn to read;
6 (b) Strategies or methods to teach children to read; and
7 (c) Approaches to overcome reading difficulties.

11 Sec. 38.2. 1. A school employee is immune from both
12 criminal and civil liability for actions taken in good faith to
13 intervene in physical altercations, fights or other incidents that
14 pose an imminent risk to the safety of pupils, other school
15 employees and persons in proximity to the altercation, fight or
16 incident, provided that:
17 (a) The school employee is acting within the course and scope
18 of his or her employment and within the course and scope of his
19 or her role in maintaining order, discipline or the safety of pupils;
20 (b) The actions of the school employee are consistent with
21 federal, state and local laws and the policies of the school district
22 employing the school employee or the school at which the school
23 employee is employed relating to the maintenance of safety and
24 discipline; and
25 (c) Any harm caused by the intervention was not the result of:
26 (1) Willful or intentional misconduct;
27 (2) Gross negligence;
28 (3) Reckless misconduct; or
29 (4) A conscious, flagrant indifference to the rights or safety
30 of the person harmed.
31 2. If any school employee intervenes in a fight or altercation
32 involving a pupil, the school employee shall report the incident to
33 school administration as soon as practicable and in accordance
34 with the policies and protocols established by the school district
35 employing the school employee or the school at which the school
36 employee is employed.
37 3. Each school or school district shall maintain a record of
38 reports received pursuant to subsection 2 and use the records only
39 to assess the need for additional training, support or policy
40 adjustments to improve school safety practices.
41 4. As used in this section:
42 (a) “Intervene” or “intervention” means taking any physical
43 or verbal action to prevent, separate or otherwise manage pupils in
44 a manner designed to avoid imminent harm to pupils, school
-
*SB460_R2*

– 131 –
1 employees or others in proximity to the area in which such actions
2 are taken.
3 (b) “School employee” means a licensed or unlicensed person
4 who is employed by:
5 (1) A board of trustees of a school district pursuant to NRS
6 391.100 or 391.281; or
7 (2) The governing body of a charter school.
8 Sec. 38.3. 1. In consultation with the Teacher and Leaders
9 Council of Nevada created by NRS 391.455, the Department shall
10 adopt regulations establishing a framework for the establishment
11 of a performance improvement plan for a postprobationary
12 administrator who receives an evaluation designating his or her
13 overall performance as ineffective or minimally effective for 2
14 consecutive school years.
15 2. A performance improvement plan must be established for
16 any postprobationary administrator who receives an evaluation
17 designating his or her overall performance as ineffective or
18 minimally effective for 2 consecutive school years.
19 3. A performance improvement plan established pursuant to
20 subsection 2 must contain clear and measurable goals for the
21 improvement of instructional practices, pupil engagement and
22 academic outcomes that are aligned with educational standards in
23 this State and that directly address areas of underperformance
24 identified in the evaluations of the postprobationary administrator.
25 4. A postprobationary administrator for whom a performance
26 improvement plan is established shall participate in programs of
27 professional development training to address the areas of
28 underperformance identified in the evaluations of the
29 postprobationary administrator, including, without limitation,
30 professional development training in:
31 (a) Instructional strategies for improving pupil engagement
32 and classroom differentiation;
33 (b) Data-driven instruction and the use of formative
34 assessments to track pupil progress; or
35 (c) Classroom management techniques and behavioral
36 interventions to promote a positive learning environment.
37 5. Each school district and governing body of a charter
38 school shall ensure that an experienced mentor or leadership
39 coach is assigned to each postprobationary administrator for
40 whom a performance improvement plan is established. The
41 mentor or leadership coach shall:
42 (a) Provide regular feedback;
43 (b) Conduct classroom observations; and
44 (c) Assist the administrator in developing and implementing
45 new instructional strategies.

31 that details the support and interventions that will be provided to

34 period of probation imposed pursuant to this section, the
35 postprobationary administrator must not be reassigned or

37 employed at another school or charter school in the school district.
38 The postprobationary administrator may be reassigned or

40 section if the reassignment or transfer is required because of low

1 transfer must not conflict with the terms of the period of probation

6 administrator has met improvement goals. If, based on the
7 evaluation, the postprobationary administrator:

39 performance improvement plan is established. The mentor or
40 instructional coach shall:
41 (a) Provide regular feedback;
42 (b) Conduct classroom observations; and
43 (c) Assist the postprobationary teacher in developing and
44 implementing new instructional strategies.

1 6. At least once each school quarter, the leadership team of
2 the school of a postprobationary teacher for whom a performance

5 goals of the performance improvement plan.
6 7. As used in this section, “leadership team” means the

8 Sec. 38.8. 1. The superintendent of schools of a school
9 district or executive director of a charter school may place a
10 postprobationary teacher on probation for a period of 2 school
11 years if, based on the evaluation of the postprobationary teacher
12 pursuant to NRS 391.690, the superintendent or executive director
13 determines that the postprobationary teacher:
14 (a) Is consistently ineffective in meeting instructional practice
15 standards, pupil performance standards and classroom
16 management standards; or
17 (b) Fails to demonstrate adequate progress under a
18 performance improvement plan established pursuant to section
19 38.7 of this act.
20 2. Upon placing a postprobationary teacher on probation
21 pursuant to subsection 1, the superintendent shall give written
22 notice to the postprobationary teacher that the postprobationary
23 teacher has been placed on probation pursuant to this section. The
24 written notice must contain an explanation of areas of
25 underperformance for which the postprobationary teacher has
26 been placed on probation pursuant to this section and a
27 performance improvement plan established pursuant to section
28 38.7 of this act that details the support and interventions that will
29 be provided to the postprobationary teacher.
30 3. Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, during a
31 period of probation imposed pursuant to this section, the
32 postprobationary teacher must not be reassigned or transferred to
33 another school in the school district or charter school or otherwise
34 employed at another school in the school district or charter school.
35 The postprobationary teacher may be reassigned or transferred
36 during a period of probation imposed pursuant to this section if
37 the reassignment or transfer is required because of low
38 enrollment, program elimination or other district-wide or school-
39 wide operational needs. Any such transfer or reassignment must
40 be made in accordance with the policies and procedures of the
41 school district or charter school, and such reassignment or
42 transfer must not conflict with the terms of the period of probation
43 imposed pursuant to this section.
44 4. Upon the conclusion of a period of probation imposed
45 pursuant to this section, the postprobationary teacher must be
-
*SB460_R2*

– 137 –
1 evaluated to determine whether the postprobationary teacher has
2 met improvement goals. If, based on the evaluation, the
3 postprobationary teacher:
4 (a) Has met the improvement goals, the postprobationary
5 teacher must be removed from probation.
6 (b) Has shown improvement and progress toward meeting the
7 improvement goals, the period of probation imposed pursuant to
8 this section may be extended for 1 additional school year and the
9 postprobationary teacher must continue to receive support and
10 monitoring under a performance improvement plan established
11 pursuant to section 38.7 of this act.
12 (c) Has failed to make adequate progress toward achieving the
13 improvement goals, the postprobationary teacher may be given
14 notice pursuant to NRS 391.820 that the postprobationary teacher
15 will not be reemployed or the superintendent or executive director
16 may initiate the process for dismissing the postprobationary
17 teacher pursuant to NRS 391.822, 391.824 and 391.826.
18 5. A postprobationary teacher who is placed on probation
19 pursuant to this section shall be deemed a probationary employee
20 for the purposes of NRS 391.650 to 391.826, inclusive, and must
21 serve an additional probationary period in accordance with NRS
22 391.820, except that the duration of that probationary period must
23 be determined in accordance with the provisions of this section.
24 6. The postprobationary teacher placed on probation
25 pursuant to this section:
26 (a) Shall not be reemployed pursuant to NRS 391.820 or shall
27 be dismissed pursuant to NRS 391.822, 391.824 and 391.826 if the
28 postprobationary teacher is determined to have failed to meet the
29 objectives in the performance improvement plan established for
30 the postprobationary teacher and the dismissal is in the best
31 interest of the pupils and the school.
32 (b) May be reassigned or have any other consequences
33 imposed only if compelling evidence demonstrates extenuating
34 circumstances contributing to the underperformance and it is in
35 the best interest of the pupils in the school for the teacher to be
36 reassigned or have other consequences imposed.
37 7. The Department shall provide support to a school district
38 or charter school that does not reemploy or dismisses a

40 may include, without limitation:

4 Sec. 56.5. 1. The Education Service Center is hereby
5 created as an educational service agency for the purpose of acting
6 as an educational service agency under 34 C.F.R. § 300.12 to
7 develop, manage and provide services and programs to local
8 educational agencies and, as necessary, to other local
9 governments.
10 2. The governing body of the Education Service Center is the
11 Board of the Education Service Center, which must consist of the
12 following members:
13 (a) Two members appointed by the Governor;
14 (b) One member, who must not be a Legislator, appointed by
15 the Majority Leader of the Senate;
16 (c) One member, who must not be a Legislator, appointed by
17 the Minority Leader of the Senate;
18 (d) One member, who must not be a Legislator, appointed by
19 the Speaker of the Assembly;
20 (e) One member, who must not be a Legislator, appointed by
21 the Minority Leader of the Assembly; and
22 (f) One member appointed by the State Board.
23 3. The Superintendent of Public Instruction shall call the
24 first meeting of the Board of the Education Service Center. At its
25 first meeting and annually thereafter, the members of the Board
26 shall elect a Chair and Vice Chair from among the members of the
27 Board. After its first meeting, the Board shall meet as needed at
28 the call of the Chair.
29 4. Each member of the Board of the Education Service
30 Center:
31 (a) Serves without compensation; and
32 (b) While engaged in the business of the Education Service
33 Center, is entitled to receive the travel expenses provided for state
34 officers and employees generally.
35 5. Each member of the Board of the Education Service
36 Center serves a term of 2 years and may be reappointed for
37 additional terms of 2 years in the same manner as the original
38 appointment. Any vacancy occurring in the membership of the
39 Board must be filled in the same manner as the original
40 appointment not later than 30 days after the vacancy occurs.
41 6. Within the limits of available money:
42 (a) The Board of the Education Service Center may appoint an
43 Executive Director. The Executive Director shall not pursue any
44 other business or occupation or hold any other office of profit
45 without the approval of the Board.
-
*SB460_R2*

– 164 –
1 (b) The Executive Director may employ such staff as is
2 necessary to the performance of the functions of the Education
3 Service Center.
4  The Executive Director and any staff of the Education Service
5 Center are eligible to participate in the Public Employees’ Benefits
6 Program and the Public Employees’ Retirement System.
7 7. The Education Service Center:
8 (a) May not impose or levy any tax or borrow money or incur
9 indebtedness.
10 (b) May apply for any available grants and accept any
11 available gifts, grants, appropriations or donations, and use any
12 such gifts, grants, appropriations or donations to carry out its
13 purposes.
14 (c) May enter into agreements with any agency or political
15 subdivision of this State, including, without limitation, counties,
16 cities and school districts, for the purpose of carrying out the
17 purposes set forth in this section.
18 8. The Education Service Center:
19 (a) May carry out activities set forth in this title, on behalf of
20 the Department, and provide services to local educational agencies
21 throughout this State, including, without limitation, services that
22 require specialized personnel.
23 (b) Shall provide support for the initiatives and efforts of this
24 State to improve the performance of schools and school districts in
25 this State, including, without limitation, evidence-based and
26 research-based support for the improvement of schools and school
27 districts identified for rigorous interventions pursuant to the
28 provisions of sections 14.25 to 14.6, inclusive, of this act.
29 (c) Shall implement or support the implementation of state or
30 federally funded initiatives assigned to the Education Service
31 Center by the Superintendent of Public Instruction.
32 (d) Shall avoid duplication of programs and services to ensure
33 a streamlined and efficient delivery of educational services.
34 9. The Superintendent of Public Instruction may adopt
35 regulations to prescribe operational aspects of the Education
36 Service Center, including, without limitation, accountability,
37 finance and budgeting, qualifications for the Board and
38 employees of the Education Service Center and procedures for
39 contracting.
40 10. The Education Service Center is hereby deemed a local
41 educational agency, as defined in 20 U.S.C. § 7801(30)(A), for all
42 purposes.

34 Sec. 58.7. Chapter 394 of NRS is hereby amended by adding
35 thereto a new section to read as follows:
36 1. A school employee is immune from both criminal and civil
37 liability for actions taken in good faith to intervene in physical
38 altercations, fights or other incidents that pose an imminent risk to
39 the safety of pupils, other school employees and persons in
40 proximity to the altercation, fight or incident, provided that:
41 (a) The school employee is acting within the course and scope
42 of his or her employment and within the course and scope of his
43 or her role in maintaining order, discipline or the safety of pupils;
44 (b) The actions of the school employee are consistent with
45 federal, state and local laws and the policies of the school district
-
*SB460_R2*

– 169 –
1 employing the school employee or the school at which the school
2 employee is employed relating to the maintenance of safety and
3 discipline; and
4 (c) Any harm caused by the intervention was not the result of:
5 (1) Willful or intentional misconduct;
6 (2) Gross negligence;
7 (3) Reckless misconduct; or
8 (4) A conscious, flagrant indifference to the rights or safety
9 of the person harmed.
10 2. If any school employee intervenes in a fight or altercation
11 involving a pupil, the school employee shall report the incident to
12 school administration as soon as practicable and in accordance
13 with the policies and protocols established by the school employing
14 the school employee.
15 3. Each school shall maintain a record of reports received
16 pursuant to subsection 2 and use these records only to assess the
17 need for additional training, support or policy adjustments to
18 improve school safety practices.
19 4. As used in this section:
20 (a) “Intervene” or “intervention” means taking any physical
21 or verbal action to prevent, separate or otherwise manage pupils in
22 a manner designed to avoid imminent harm to pupils, school
23 employees or others in proximity to the area where such actions
24 are taken.
25 (b) “School employee” means a licensed or unlicensed person
26 who is employed by a private school.

3 Sec. 60. Chapter 179A of NRS is hereby amended by adding
4 thereto a new section to read as follows:
5 1. The Department of Education, may, at no cost to the
6 Department of Education, participate in the Rap Back Program
7 administered in this State by the Central Repository. The Central
8 Repository may retain fingerprints and submit fingerprints to the
9 Federal Bureau of Investigation for the purpose of enabling the
10 Department of Education to receive ongoing status notifications of
11 any criminal history of a person who is licensed by the
12 Superintendent of Public Instruction pursuant to NRS 391.033 if
13 the subscription to the service is active. For the purposes of the
14 Rap Back Program, the Department of Education is hereby
15 deemed to be an authorized entity that engages in the licensing of
16 educational personnel pursuant to NRS 391.033.
17 2. Any fingerprints forwarded to the Central Repository for
18 the purpose of licensure pursuant to NRS 391.033 must be
19 retained in the state and federal Next Generation Identification
20 Systems for the purpose of participating in the Rap Back Program
21 and being searched by future submissions to the state and federal
22 Next Generation Identification Systems, including, without
23 limitation, latent fingerprint searches.
24 3. The Central Repository shall establish a means of
25 collecting, using, safeguarding, handling, retaining, storing,
26 disseminating and destroying any records of criminal history in
27 accordance with the provisions of this chapter and chapter 179A
28 of NRS and the Security Policy and the Administrative Policies of
29 the Nevada Criminal Justice Information System adopted as
30 regulations by the Central Repository.
31 4. The Department of Education shall:
32 (a) Before retaining the fingerprints of a person in the state
33 and federal Next Generation Identification Systems for the
34 purpose of participating in the Rap Back Program, obtain the
35 consent of the person to retain the fingerprints and release
36 information concerning his or her criminal history to the
37 Department of Education.
38 (b) Notify the Central Repository, in a form and manner
39 prescribed by the Central Repository, when a person licensed
40 pursuant to NRS 391.033 is no longer licensed pursuant to that
41 section. Upon receiving such notice, the Central Repository shall:
42 (1) Destroy any printed and electronic fingerprint cards
43 and facsimiles of fingerprints that the Central Repository has
44 retained for the person as part of the Rap Back Program; and
-
*SB460_R2*

– 171 –
1 (2) Notify the Federal Bureau of Investigation that the
2 person is no longer licensed by an authorized entity and request
3 that the Federal Bureau of Investigation destroy any printed and
4 electronic fingerprint cards or facsimiles of fingerprints that the
5 Federal Bureau of Investigation has retained for the person in the
6 Rap Back Program.
7 5. As used in this section, “Rap Back Program” means a
8 system maintained by the Central Repository and the Federal
9 Bureau of Investigation that enables authorized entities to receive
10 ongoing status notifications of any criminal history reported for
11 persons whose fingerprints are retained in the Next Generation
12 Identification System maintained by Central Repository and the
13 Federal Bureau of Investigation.

17 employer is entitled to:
18 (a) Reopen a collective bargaining agreement for additional,

20 or monetary benefits during a period of fiscal emergency.
21 Negotiations must begin not later than 21 days after the local
22 government employer notifies the employee organization that a
23 fiscal emergency exists. For the purposes of this section, a fiscal
24 emergency shall be deemed to exist:
25 (1) If the amount of revenue received by the general fund of
26 the local government employer during the last preceding fiscal year
27 from all sources, except any nonrecurring source, declined by 5
28 percent or more from the amount of revenue received by the general
29 fund from all sources, except any nonrecurring source, during the
30 next preceding fiscal year, as reflected in the reports of the annual
31 audits conducted for those fiscal years for the local government
32 employer pursuant to NRS 354.624; or
33 (2) If the local government employer has budgeted an
34 unreserved ending fund balance in its general fund for the current
35 fiscal year in an amount equal to 4 percent or less of the actual
36 expenditures from the general fund for the last preceding fiscal year,
37 and the local government employer has provided a written
38 explanation of the budgeted ending fund balance to the Department
39 of Taxation that includes the reason for the ending fund balance and
40 the manner in which the local government employer plans to
41 increase the ending fund balance.
42 (b) Take whatever actions may be necessary to carry out its
43 responsibilities in situations of emergency such as a riot, military
44 action, natural disaster or civil disorder. Those actions may include

30 Sec. 70. 1. The Nevada Registered Teacher Apprenticeship
31 Support Program is hereby created in the Office of Labor
32 Commissioner. The purpose of the program is to provide grants of
33 money to sponsors of apprenticeship programs in teaching that
34 have been approved by the Council to provide:
35 (a) Wrap-around support and staffing services to recruit,
36 prepare and retain apprentices participating in an apprenticeship
37 program in teaching who desire to become licensed teachers in
38 public schools in this State; and
39 (b) Instruction, including, without limitation, professional
40 development, coaching, mentoring and induction required during
41 an apprenticeship in teaching.
42 2. The State Apprenticeship Director shall:
43 (a) Administer the Program.
44 (b) Establish requirements for eligibility to participate in the
45 Program, including, without limitation, requiring an applicant to:
-
*SB460_R2*

– 182 –
1 (1) Establish that the apprenticeship program sponsored by
2 the applicant has been approved by the Council pursuant to
3 NRS 610.095;
4 (2) Use evidence-based metrics to evaluate the success of
5 the apprenticeship program; and
6 (3) Demonstrate the capability of the applicant to
7 successfully recruit participants for the program, prepare the
8 participants to become teachers and retain the participants in a
9 public school in this State; and
10 (c) Evaluate applications submitted pursuant to this section.
11 3. In evaluating an application for a grant of money awarded
12 pursuant to this section, the State Apprenticeship Director shall
13 give priority to an applicant who:
14 (a) Complies with the requirements of subsection 2;
15 (b) Demonstrates previous success in carrying out an
16 apprenticeship program;
17 (c) Provides a plan for new or innovative wrap-around
18 supports that are determined to be of high quality by the State
19 Apprenticeship Director; and
20 (d) Provides a plan to efficiently use the grant of money
21 awarded pursuant to this section to maximize the number of
22 participants in an apprenticeship program who will benefit from
23 its use.
24 4. An applicant who receives a grant of money pursuant to
25 this section shall:
26 (a) Develop, in collaboration with the State Apprenticeship
27 Director, standards and goals for the program to meet, including,
28 without limitation, a desired number of pupils to participate in and
29 complete the apprenticeship program;
30 (b) Provide wrap-around services to participants in the
31 apprenticeship program; and
32 (c) Submit a report to the State Apprenticeship Director at the
33 end of each semester describing the progress of the apprenticeship
34 program in achieving the goals developed pursuant to
35 paragraph (a).
36 5. The State Apprenticeship Director shall ensure that:
37 (a) Grants of money are promptly distributed to applicants
38 selected to receive such a grant; and
39 (b) Grants of money are awarded proportional to the number
40 of participants in the apprenticeship program, provided that:
41 (1) Not more than $4,000 is awarded for each participant;
42 and
43 (2) A participant is counted for the purposes of calculating
44 the amount of a grant for not more than 2 years.
-

10 educators.
11 2. The Department shall use the portal described in subsection
12 1 to monitor, without limitation:
13 (a) The average class size in this State;
14 (b) The access a school district has to teachers with classroom
15 experience;
16 (c) The use of long-term substitutes by school districts in this
17 State;
18 (d) The average and median age of teachers employed by school
19 districts in this State;
20 (e) The ratio of the members of a school staff who are licensed
21 to the members of a school staff who are not licensed; and
22 (f) Metrics that describe the ability of school districts in this
23 State to hire teachers who were enrolled in a program for teacher
24 and educator preparation established by an institution within the
25 Nevada System of Higher Education.

7 Sec. 81. 1. The Commission on School Funding created by
8 NRS 387.1246 shall conduct an interim study concerning public
9 school funding. The study must include, without limitation, an
10 examination of:
11 (a) The efficiency of developing reporting requirements relating
12 to education, including, without limitation, accountability of school
13 districts and whether such reporting requirements should be
14 consolidated or eliminated, including, without limitation, whether
15 the Department of Education should create a portal to receive such
16 consolidated data;
17 (b) The capacity of the Department to properly store and collect
18 data received from school districts and whether data requested from
19 school districts and charter schools by state agencies other than the
20 Department should be coordinated through the Department to ensure
21 efficiency;
22 (c) The levels of funding and staffing that are necessary for the
23 adequate implementation of multi-tiered systems of supports in
24 schools in this State;
25 (d) The ability of school districts to implement a consistent
26 method of recording and allocating costs within the school district;
27 (e) Adequate levels of staffing that are necessary for meeting the
28 needs of pupils;
29 (f) Whether there is a better method of optimizing the weight
30 relative to base per pupil funding that is given to pupils described in
31 paragraph (e) of subsection 2 of NRS 387.1214 and 387.122;
32 (g) The funding necessary to ensure that the Department is
33 adequately staffed and has the appropriate resources it needs,
34 including, without limitation, technological resources;
35 (h) Methods used by other states to identify at-risk pupils and
36 whether this State should use similar methods; and
37 (i) Funding for charter schools in this State, including, without
38 limitation:
39 (1) The provision of funds from the Federal Government and
40 this State; and
41 (2) The use of such funding for, without limitation, the
42 provision of special education and related services, transportation
43 services and facilities.

5 Sec. 81.5. 1. One or more institutions within the Nevada
6 System of Higher Education may establish and operate a pilot
7 program to offer an alternative pathway for assessing the
8 competency of applicants for a license to teach pupils in this State
9 through the use of alternative assessment methods.
10 2. A pilot program established pursuant to subsection 1 must:
11 (a) Select not more than 100 participants for the pilot program
12 each academic year;
13 (b) Select not more than 25 teachers licensed pursuant to chapter
14 391 of NRS who have taught in a public school in this State for at
15 least 5 years to serve as mentors for participants in the pilot
16 program;
17 (c) Include a curriculum of professional development for
18 participants in the pilot program that consists of at least 10 sessions
19 and is aligned with the criteria for designating a teacher as effective
20 or highly effective under the statewide performance evaluation
21 system established by the State Board of Education pursuant to
22 NRS 391.465;
23 (d) Require, for the duration of the pilot program, a teacher
24 selected to serve as a mentor pursuant to paragraph (b) to conduct a
25 monthly meeting with each participant who is assigned as his or her
26 mentee;
27 (e) For a participant to receive credit for satisfactorily
28 completing the pilot program, require the participant to, while he or
29 she is participating in the pilot program, receive at least two
30 consecutive evaluations, conducted pursuant to NRS 391.685, in
31 which the overall performance of the teacher was designated as
32 effective or highly effective;
33 (f) For alternative assessment methods, assess the validity and
34 reliability of the methods and ability of the methods to be scaled to
35 accommodate a greater number of participants;
36 (g) Promote assessment practices that are inclusive and
37 equitable and that support a diversity of learning styles and
38 experiences;
39 (h) Align alternative assessment methods with applicable state
40 standards, requirements for accreditation and the needs of school
41 districts in this State; and
42 (i) Collect and analyze data to provide evidence-based
43 recommendations for the potential implementation of alternative
44 assessment methods in this State.
-
*SB460_R2*

1 3. A person is eligible to participate in a pilot program
2 established pursuant to this section if he or she is an applicant for a
3 license to teach issued pursuant to chapter 391 of NRS and holds;
4 (a) A provisional license issued by the Superintendent of Public
5 Instruction pursuant to NRS 391.032;
6 (b) A special license as an emergency substitute teacher issued
7 by the Department of Education; or
8 (c) An endorsement to serve as a substitute teacher in early
9 childhood education through grade 12 issued by the State Board of
10 Education.
11 4. The Department of Education shall:
12 (a) For each participant in the pilot program established
13 pursuant to this section, extend for 24 months after selection
14 participate in the pilot program any deadline for removing a
15 provision on a provisional license issued by the Superintendent of
16 Public Instruction pursuant to NRS 391.032 that requires
17 successfully passing a competency test required to receive an initial
18 license to teach pursuant to NRS 391.021.
19 (b) Upon successful completion of the pilot program by a
20 participant who holds a provisional license issued by the
21 Superintendent of Public Instruction pursuant to NRS 391.032,
22 remove any provision on the provisional license issued to the
23 applicant which requires the applicant to pass a competency test in
24 the principles and methods of teaching.
25 5. Each institution that offers a pilot program pursuant to this
26 section shall:
27 (a) On or before July 1 of each year of operation of the pilot
28 program established pursuant to this section:
29 (1) Compile a report describing the progress of the pilot
30 program, including, without limitation:
31 (I) Demographic information for participants in the pilot
32 program;
33 (II) The success of professional development services
34 provided by the pilot program;
35 (III) Preliminary findings of the pilot program.
36 (2) Submit the report compiled pursuant to subparagraph (1)
37 to:
38 (I) The Director of the Legislative Counsel Bureau for
39 transmittal to the Joint Interim Standing Committee on Education;
40 (II) The State Board of Education; and
41 (III) The Commission on Professional Standards in
42 Education.
43 (b) Not later than 6 months after the pilot program established
44 pursuant to this section ceases operation, submit to the Department
45 of Education:

1 (1) A plan for implementing the pilot program in a
2 permanent format that can accommodate all prospective applicants

5 6. As used in this section:
6 (a) “Alternative assessment methods” means valid and reliable
7 methods used for determining, for an initial license to teach issued
8 pursuant to NRS 391.019, the applicant’s competency in, knowledge
9 of and ability to provide instruction in accordance with sound
10 principles and methods of teaching appropriate to the applicant’s
11 required level of competence that is equivalent to the “Principles of
12 Learning and Teaching Test” prepared and administered by the
13 Educational Testing Service.
14 (b) “Metrics of success” includes, without limitation:
15 (1) An evaluation of the growth in competency, professional
16 engagement and readiness for participants in the pilot program
17 established pursuant to this section;
18 (2) An analysis of the impact of the pilot program on the
19 retention, effectiveness and morale of teachers; and
20 (3) Benchmarks for satisfactory completion of the pilot
21 program.
22 (c) “Participant” means an applicant for a license to teach who is
23 selected to participate in the pilot program established pursuant to
24 this section.
